title: Skirt (Democratic Republic of the Congo), late 19th century
medium:
Medium: raffia
Technique: plain weave, pieced and sewn, with twisted warp fringes
Label: woven raffia, pieced and sewn, with twisted warp fringes
creditline: Museum purchase from Au Panier Fleuri Fund
description: Rectangular panel composed of four strips of woven raffia with twisted warp fringes. Each strip is composed of smaller pieces, stitched together with dark raffia strands.
gallery_text: The Teke were famous traders, situated at the river gateway between the Atlantic and the remainder of the Kuba kingdom. This superior trading position meant that they were the first to replace traditional raffia cloths with imported cottons, making skirts like this one particularly rare. Missionary John Weeks, who arrived in the area in 1882, recounted in Among the Primitive Bakongo the incredible fineness of the “palm frondlet” textiles, while Frederick Starr, arriving in 1905, noted the prevalence of imported fabric. Plain raffia squares were used as currency or stitched together to form textiles. Although this rare Teke skirt is unadorned, the seams joining the individual panels reflect the waters that separate the earth from the sky in Teke cosmology, and the fringes are symbols of chiefhood.

tombstone.epitaph:
Skirt (Democratic Republic of the Congo), late 19th century. Medium: raffia
Technique: plain weave, pieced and sewn, with twisted warp fringes
Label: woven raffia, pieced and sewn, with twisted warp fringes. 
Museum purchase from Au Panier Fleuri Fund. 1957-110-1
